div.p:
Maria and I have had this
evening our usual dispute about the second-
-rate importance, or, the preeminence of memory,
among the faculties of the mind -
Mr
Mrs
Mr Butler
occasionally joined sometimes on one side
sometimes on the other and always sensibly
and She supported her argument with
extraordinary ingenuity and with various
amusing & apposite illustrations, for which
take notice she was indebted to the very
faculty that she was underrating. - The
grand question remains in both our views of
the subject - How is the memory to be managed
? - A good memory to be made recollection? -
or a bad memory to be assisted. - Lovell throws
out some useful hints - such as leading chil-
dren children to exercises which require the joint combi-
nation combination of ing invention & memory - as practiced
at his school - Mental arithmetic, where the
child (suppose in multiplying a sum by two figures)
is obliged to have recourse to some means of recollecting
the multiplicand of the 1st. figure in order to
have it ready to add to that of the 2d. figure. It is
a highly interesting subject and I endeavoured
to excite her to put together all the hints she could
collect, and at some future time to tell us all that
can be done to ourselves and to our pupils, instead
of eternally repeating with Locke & Reid and a hundred
others the mere words "Arrange the facts you acquire"
"Connect your ideas by links" "Association is the
grand key to the storehouse of the mind" &c &c

How I am running on! though I only alluded
to the subject in order to add that I think I had
good reason to leave off in the same opinion that
I began - and at least to complain of my own
want of this valuable quality as on sitting down
now to write to you I cannot recollect whether
in the letter I dispatched to you from Trim I
entered into any description of my adventures
then amongst the decaying castles convents
and churches of former times. For fear however
of the "hateful twice told tale" I shall pass over
them (trusting to my poor memory to recall the
subject when I have the delight of returning
to your arms and to your ears) and proceed
with my onward journey. - Wednesday at
11 we started from Trim Vicarage, and, along with
us, Mr & Mrs. Butler in their carriage. We went by
the pretty Killucan road to Mullingar - Rathoan -
where we met the
Edgh. Edgeworth
horses and arrived at 5 -
having drawn in a little to allow Mr & Mrs. B. Butler
to form
part of the large group that was assembled on
the lawn to receive Aunt Mary in the home of
her choice. Some cried some smiled - some were silent and
some talked in full exuberance of heart; - the meeting
was really affectingly pleasing. - The evening
was brilliantly fine and the sun seemed to loiter
over the western hills, for much was yet to be done.
When dark an immense bonfire suddenly blazed
up in front of the house and gave the signal to
the whole population of the town who poured into
the lawn preceded by a band of music playing
"Why should old acquaintance be forgotten." The crowd drew up and gave three
cheers - not very harmonious indeed from the pre-
ponderance preponderance of screaming women & shrill children
but given with all their might & heart - This was
repeated and again and again renewed till I began
to feel "How is this to end?" - I therefore suggested
to Lovell to stand up on the steps and thank
the multitude in Aunt Mary's name. He took
the hint - and having a made a very decent
speech the people gave another noble yell and m
out again with pipe and drum. - All hands that
dared to trust themselves in the dewy breath of Heaven
now walked up the town which was splendidly illu-
minated illuminated - every pane of every window having a candle
stuck in it - and every pane had been cleaned that
no twinkle might be lost, and that the laurel, the
oak, the rose and RoseMary might be the more conspicuous.
- The street was quite full - parties kept roaring
longlife to K. G. the 4th. and the Royal family - Mister
Ejowrth and Mrs Mary Sneyd for ever - and some
wags added And O'Connel too. - One of their gambols
was placing a lighted tar barrel on a large slate which
4 men paraded on their shoulders. - Poor Aunt
Mary indeed the object of all this rude & clamorous
but I do believe sincere effusion of joy, was precluded
from witnessing it - for she was too blind to enjoy the effort - but she heard
in the library frequent reports of what was doing -and she must have been
much more than woman if she did not feel something of the intoxication
of popularity - And who could deserve it better? - Would to Heaven
that the noisy throats of mobs were never strained in a worse cause - in
chusing the licentious despot - in the war howl of welcome to the blood stained
conqueror - or in the acclamation of the wily demagogue who laughs at the
enthusi-
-asm enthusiasm which he knows how to fire but never felt. - By eleven (the Mail Coach
having passed "& wondered at the work" that was going on) all the Town lights were
out - and the library was filled with 17 happy people who
again congratulated the excellent heroine of the day, and at length
allowed her to retire to a repose which the termination of a long journey
and the excitement of the evening made necessary. - I must now
and waken William who is going in the Mail Coach to Sligo on his
way to Donegal where he has some Engineering works, and
from whence he came to receive his Aunt - So Good night

Saturday. Visitors have begun to pour in
and from A.M. will be congratulated without
quarter. -
